moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. e3 b6 3. Nf3 Bb7 4. c4 e6 5: Having lost several games one after another I am trying to play very carefully. Builing up something like a Colle system.
moves.5... d6: Very quite too. Black and White still haven't "touched" each other.
moves.6. O-O: Usual development - preparing rook to e1 and Queen to c2 to increase pressure on e4 (which will eventually follow)
moves.7. Nc3: Developing another piece - more pressure on e4
moves.7... O-O 8. e4: Occupying more space and thinking about attacking knight on f6 - main black king defender.
moves.8... Nbd7 9. Qc2: Aligning queen with the bishop on d3 - preparing attack on h7 once the black knight is removed.
moves.9... g6: As a rule says - Delay your castling pawns moves as long as you can. By moving this pawn black created a weakness on black squares.
moves.10. Bh6: which white is trying to use - developing bishop with a tempo
moves.10... Re8: has to move. White has advantage in terms of space.
moves.11. h3: Preventing black knight from developing to g4 - white want black to stay in that "compact" state.
moves.11... Bf8: Obviously, black doesn't like that white bishop
moves.12. Qd2: Since attack on h7 is not going to happen, moving queen to a better square protecting the bishop
moves.12... Bg7: Surprise - This black bishop can become quite strong on this diagonal. Also it is a black king defender
moves.13... Kxg7 14. e5: Trying to open up this position a little
moves.15... dxe5: Black also doesn't mind to open it up.
moves.16. d5: keeping black's white-squared bishop diagonal closed. Pawn on e5 is weak.
moves.17... a6: protecting b5 square  -both knight on c3 and bishop on d3 wouldn't mind to get there!
moves.18. f4: White wants to bring heavy artillery into the game - rook on f1
moves.20. Rae1: Supporting pawn on e5 and bringing another rook into the game. Mistake - should have played Rc3. White queen is overloaded - protecting 2 pieces at once (knight on g5 and bishop on d3)
moves.22. e6: White's pieces are better developed - pushing pawns forward with the idea to open up the black king more
moves.25. Qc4: White is 1 piece down, so no trading queens at this stage! instead white attacks the c7 pawn AND prepares the discovered check (pawn d6) AND still attacking the black queen
moves.25... Kh8: Fatal mistake - this also happens to me - when analysing different ways to respond you forget the obvious - the queen is still under attack.
